## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Mars)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-01-30T15:19:51Z
## Message ID: 20160130-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:


C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO.

Start time of the event: 2016-01-29T21:17Z.

Estimated speed: ~856 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 35 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 85/-24 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2016-01-29T21:17:00-CME-001


Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Mars (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME will reach Mars at 2016-02-03T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours).


Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2016-01-29T21:17:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160130_014200_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for January 20, 2016 - January 26, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-01-28T01:15:04Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-01-20T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-01-26T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160128-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period.  There were 2 C-type CMEs (see details below). Based on heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME starting on 2016-01-26T18:12Z may impact Mars and NASA missions near Earth. For 48 ensemble members simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach Mars between about 2016-01-30T16:20Z and 2016-01-31T12:07Z (average arrival 2016-01-31T01:17Z) for 97% of simulation, and NASA missions near Earth between about 2016-01-29T01:29Z and 2016-01-29T09:22Z (average arrival 2016-01-29T05:31Z) for 20% of simulations (glancing blow).  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 96% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-5 range (below minor to minor) (see notifications 20160127-AL-003 and 20160127-AL-004). It was also estimated that the CME may impact Juno (glancing blow) at 2016-02-14T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20160127-AL-005).

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=6 occurred during the synoptic period 2016-01-21T03:00Z to 2016-01-21T06:00Z. This elevation in geomagnetic activity was associated with combined effects of the CME impact that started on 2016-01-15T00:00Z (see notifications 20160115-AL-001, 20160115-AL-002) and the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 early on 2016-01-21 (see notifications 20160121-AL-001 and 20160121-AL-002).  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level during the reporting period.  GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux was above 10^5 pfu starting at 2016-01-24T15:05Z.  This elevation in electron fluxes was associated with the arrival of the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notifications 20160124-AL-001 and 20160124-AL-002).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the enhancement of the electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-01-26T18:12Z     ~820            C                55/-30               35                          SOHO                              


Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-01-22T19:12Z     ~541            C                 2/-38               22                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-01-27T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-02-02T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are a few active region on the solar disk with potential to produce solar flares and coronal mass ejections. We are also expecting some geomagnetic disturbance due to the arrival of the CME expected on 2016-01-29 and also the arrival of the northern hemisphere coronal hole high speed stream.

## Summary:

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is also estimated that the CME may impact Juno (glancing blow). ## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME update (ensemble) (Mars, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-01-27T16:37:23Z
## Message ID: 20160127-AL-004
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2016-01-26T18:12:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20160127-AL-003). Based on heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Mars. For 48 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- Mars between about 2016-01-30T16:20Z and 2016-01-31T12:07Z (average arrival 2016-01-31T01:17Z) for 97% of simulations.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2016-01-29T01:29Z and 2016-01-29T09:22Z (average arrival 2016-01-29T05:31Z) for 20% of simulations (glancing arrival).  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 96% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-5 range (below minor to minor).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2016-01-26_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX052/20160126_181200_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX052_anim_tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2016-01-26_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX052/20160126_181200_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX052_arrival_Earth.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2016-01-26_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX052/20160126_181200_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX052_Earth_stack.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2016-01-26_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX052/20160126_181200_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX052_probabilistic_Kp_forecast_wdist.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2016-01-26_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX052/20160126_181200_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX052_arrival_Mars.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2016-01-26_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX052/20160126_181200_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX052_Mars_stack.gif

## Notes:
Ensemble CME modeling at SWRC is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2016-01-26_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX052/Detailed_results_20160126_181200_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX052.txt

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2016-01-26T18:12Z.

Estimated speed: ~802 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 37 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 61/-32 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2016-01-26T18:12:00-CME-001

 
Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that this CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2016-01-18T12:38Z (plus minus 7 hours). This CME could be a glancing blow. The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 2-5 (below minor to minor).

## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for January 13, 2016 - January 19, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-01-22T01:19:23Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-01-13T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-01-19T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160122-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.     

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2016-01-13T00:00Z-06:00Z and 2016-01-19T00:00Z-03:00Z.  The slight increase in geomagnetic activity on 2016-01-19 was due to the CME (starting on 2016-01-15T00:00Z) arrival detected by ACE at L1 around 2016-01-18T21:00Z (see notifications 20160115-AL-001 and 20160115-AL-002).  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:

Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-01-20T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-01-26T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are active regions on the solar disk capable of producing solar flares and coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity increased on 2016-01-20 and 2016-01-21 due to the lingering effects of the CME that started on 2016-01-15T00:00Z and the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 early on 2016-01-21.

## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME update (ensemble) (Mars, missions near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-01-15T21:37:27Z
## Message ID: 20160115-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME(s) with ID(s) 2016-01-15T00:00:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20160115-AL-001)..... Based on heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Mars. For 32 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- Mars between about 2016-01-20T07:00Z and 2016-01-20T17:48Z (average arrival 2016-01-20T14:50Z) for 40% of simulations.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2016-01-18T02:22Z and 2016-01-18T12:20Z (average arrival 2016-01-18T07:54Z) for 71% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 96% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-5 range (below minor to minor).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2016-01-15_ncmes1_sims32_HILOX051/20160115_000005_ncmes1_sims32_HILOX051_anim_tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2016-01-15_ncmes1_sims32_HILOX051/20160115_000005_ncmes1_sims32_HILOX051_arrival_Earth.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2016-01-15_ncmes1_sims32_HILOX051/20160115_000005_ncmes1_sims32_HILOX051_Earth_stack.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2016-01-15_ncmes1_sims32_HILOX051/20160115_000005_ncmes1_sims32_HILOX051_probabilistic_Kp_forecast_wdist.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2016-01-15_ncmes1_sims32_HILOX051/20160115_000005_ncmes1_sims32_HILOX051_arrival_Mars.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2016-01-15_ncmes1_sims32_HILOX051/20160115_000005_ncmes1_sims32_HILOX051_Mars_stack.gif

## Notes:
Ensemble CME modeling at SWRC is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:

## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were 3 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2016-01-06T00:00Z-03:00Z.  This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 on 2016-01-05.  The solar wind speed reached values of 669 km/s.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES was at background levels for the reporting period. The 13-100 MeV proton flux at STEREO A had a small increase due to the arrival of the 2016-01-06T14:24Z CME starting on 2016-01-09 and went back to the background levels around 2016-01-11T00:00Z.  

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for December 30, 2015 - January 05, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-01-07T15:57:29Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2015-12-30T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-01-05T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160107-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate level during this reporting period with 1 M-class flare (see list below).  There were 2 C-type CMEs, 1 O-type CME(see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp index has reached level  6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2016-01-01T00:00Z to 2016-01-01T03:00Z. The increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of the CME that started on 2015-12-28T12:39:00 and detected by ACE at L1 on 2015-12-31T00:02Z (see notifications  20151228-AL-001,  20151228-AL-002, 20151229-AL-001, 20151231-AL-001 and 20151231-AL-002).

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2016-01-02T12:25Z . This elevation was caused by the arrival of the CME and the geomagnetic storm mentioned above (see notifications 20160102-AL-003  and 20160102-AL-004).

Solar energetic particle event was detected by GOES when the flux of > 10 MeV protons exceeded 10 pfu starting at 2016-01-02T04:30Z. This event is associated with M2.3 class flare which peaked at 2015-01-02T00:10Z and a following CME that started at  2016-01-01T23:12:00 (see notifications 2016-01-01T23:00:00-FLR-001 and  2016-01-01T23:12:00-CME-001).  Solar energetic particle event was detected also by SOHO.  The flux of one or more of the >15.8 MeV protons channels exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2016-01-02T02:48Z. This event is also related to the  M2.3 class mentioned above and the CME that started at 2016-01-01T23:12:00. The energetic proton flux of 13-100 MeV protons detected at STEREO A was at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate this week due to the elevated energetic particle fluxes.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-01-02T15:05:59Z
## Message ID: 20160102-AL-005
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

O-type CME detected by SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2016-01-01T23:12Z.

Estimated speed: ~1588 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 37 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 73/-34 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

NASA spacecraft near Earth as well as Juno may be affected.  Updates on this event will be provided when available.

Activity ID: 2016-01-01T23:12:00-CME-001

## Notes: 

This CME event (2016-01-01T23:12:00-CME-001) is associated with 2.3 flare with ID 2016-01-01T23:00:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2015-01-02T00:10Z, SEP at SOHO with ID 2016-01-02T02:48:00-SEP-001 (see notification(s) 20160102-AL-002), and SEP at GOES13 with ID 2016-01-02T04:30:00-SEP-001 (see notification(s) 20160102-AL-001).

[1] http://iswawiki.gsfc.nasa.gov/wiki/index.php/Glossary/Heliospheric_Earth_Equatorial_coordinates

SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-01-02T13:30:12Z
## Message ID: 20160102-AL-004
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2016-01-02T12:25Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by CME with ID 2015-12-28T12:39:00-CME-001 (see notification(s) 20151228-AL-001, 20151228-AL-002, 20151229-AL-001).

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-01-02T12:25:00-RBE-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - SEP Update
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-01-02T04:51:39Z
## Message ID: 20160102-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar energetic particle event detected by SOHO and GOES.  The flux of the >15.8 MeV protons channels at SOHO exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2016-01-02T02:48Z. The flux of the > 10 MeV protons at GOES exceeded 10 pfu starting at 2016-01-02T04:30Z.

NASA spacecraft at MEO, GEO and other high-altitude orbits and high-inclination LEO can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-01-02T02:48:00-SEP-001.

## Notes: 

This SEP event (2016-01-02T02:48:00-SEP-001) is associated with M2.3 class flare with ID 2016-01-01T23:00:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2015-01-02T00:10Z.
